title: SB 1325
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 25247 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to require the department to review and approve plans submitted under Section 25246 if they comply with regulations and state/federal laws. Approval is contingent on meeting requirements under the Water Code. The department must approve a plan under Section 25246 of the Health and Safety Code if it meets regulations and laws, including those in the Water Code. Approval can happen after approval under Water Code Section 13227, 60 days after submission by an interim status facility, or if immediate approval is needed for public health, safety, or the environment. Any department action under this section is subject to Section 25204.5. The director may approve a plan under Section 25246 of the Health and Safety Code if it meets regulations and laws, including those in the Water Code. Immediate approval may be necessary to protect public health, safety, or the environment. Department actions are subject to Section 25204.5, and hazardous waste facility postclosure requirements can be imposed on owners or operators through enforcement orders, agreements, or permits. The department can impose hazardous waste facility postclosure requirements on owners or operators through enforcement orders, agreements, or permits, subject to Section 25204.5. The plan must comply with the California Environmental Quality Act. The hazardous waste facility postclosure plan imposed or modified must comply with the California Environmental Quality Act. The department must allow public involvement before approving or modifying the plan. (C) A "significant modification" is determined by the department based on whether it would be classified as a class 3 permit modification for hazardous waste facilities. The department considers similarities to class 3 modifications in regulations and public concerns when making this determination. The department determines if a modification is significant by comparing it to class 3 modifications in regulations and considering public concerns. The department has the authority to order necessary actions at a facility to protect public health or safety. If the department imposes a hazardous waste facility postclosure plan through an enforcement order or agreement, the owner must pay a specified fee or enter a cost reimbursement agreement. The fee must also be paid at the start of the postclosure period. Upon commencement of the postclosure period, the owner must pay the fee required by paragraph (9) of subdivision (c) of Section 25205.4. The postclosure period begins on the effective date of the postclosure permit, enforcement order, or enforceable agreement. The department may enforce a postclosure plan through actions such as filing an injunction, requiring corrective action, and assessing civil penalties for violations. The department may enforce a postclosure plan by requiring corrective action, assessing civil penalties for violations, and filing actions to recover fines. This does not apply to plans with permits issued before December 31, 2003, unless mutually replaced with an enforcement order or agreement. On or before January 1, 2018, the department must adopt regulations for postclosure plan requirements under subdivision (d), excluding plans with permits issued before December 31, 2003, unless mutually replaced with an enforcement order or agreement. The department must adopt regulations by January 1, 2018, for postclosure plan requirements. If deemed necessary, the department can replace an enforcement order with a postclosure permit for a hazardous waste facility. The department has the authority to order actions to protect public health and the environment at a facility. Section 25247 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to require the department to review and approve plans that comply with regulations and state/federal laws before approval. The department must approve a plan for a facility under certain conditions, including approval under Water Code Section 13227, submission for 60 days without denial, or immediate approval for public health or safety. Any department action is subject to Section 25204.5. The director may approve a plan for a facility immediately if it is necessary to protect public health, safety, or the environment. Department actions are subject to Section 25204.5, and hazardous waste facility postclosure requirements can be imposed through enforcement orders, agreements, or permits. The department can impose hazardous waste facility postclosure requirements on owners or operators through enforcement orders, agreements, or permits, in compliance with the California Environmental Quality Act. The hazardous waste facility postclosure plan imposed or modified must comply with the California Environmental Quality Act. The department must allow public involvement before approving or modifying the plan, including public notice and comment. A "significant modification" for a hazardous waste facility permit is determined by the department based on similarity to class 3 modifications in regulations. Public concern is also considered in this determination. The department determines if a proposed modification for a hazardous waste facility permit is similar to class 3 modifications in regulations and considers public concern. The department has the authority to order necessary actions at a facility to protect public health and safety, regardless of permit modifications. If the department issues a hazardous waste facility postclosure plan through an enforcement order or agreement instead of a permit, the owner must enter a cost reimbursement agreement and pay the required fee at the start of the postclosure period. The postclosure period begins on the effective date of the permit, order, or agreement. The department may enforce a postclosure plan through various actions, including filing an injunction, requiring corrective action, and assessing civil penalties for violations. The department may enforce a postclosure plan by requiring corrective action, assessing civil penalties for violations, and issuing injunctions if necessary. Compliance with emergency response measures to protect human health and the environment is also mandated. The department may enforce a postclosure plan by requiring corrective action, assessing civil penalties for violations, and issuing injunctions if necessary. Compliance with emergency response measures to protect human health and the environment is mandated. Subdivision (d) exemptions apply to postclosure plans with permits issued before December 31, 2003, unless mutually replaced with an enforcement order or agreement. Regulations for postclosure plan requirements must be adopted by the department by January 1, 2018. On or before January 1, 2018, the department will adopt regulations for postclosure plan requirements. If deemed necessary, the department can replace an enforcement order with a postclosure permit for a hazardous waste facility. The department has the authority to order necessary actions at a facility to protect public health, safety, or the environment. Section 1.5 of the bill includes amendments to Section 25247 of the Health and Safety Code, contingent on the enactment of Assembly Bill 1611 or Senate Bill 839 by January 1, 2017. The amended section will only be in effect until the operative date of this bill. The bill, either Bill 1611 or Senate Bill 839, amends Section 25247 of the Health and Safety Code. This bill is enacted last among those amending the same section, and its provisions will become operative once enacted.
